newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Cotton prices seen fluctuating in India, Pakistan.
newsitem.headline: Cotton prices seen fluctuating in India, Pakistan.

text.p: Cotton prices are likely to rise in India and dip in Pakistan in the next few days, dealers in the two countries said on Thursday.
In India, prices are expected to rise in anticipation of a government decision to authorise more exports, dealers there said.
"I expect cotton prices on the local market to recover," said leading Indian cotton trader Manubhai Amersey.
He said state-owned agencies buying cotton from farmers had been demanding more cotton exports to prop up domestic prices.

"I expect the government to allow 250,000/300,000 bales (of 170 kg each) more cotton for export," Amarsey said. "Officials of state federations are holding talks with the government. A decision may be made next month."
The government has so far authorised the export of one million bales in the 1996/97 (Oct/Sept) season.
Trade sources expect India's 1996/97 cotton crop to be around 15.5 million bales, marginally below the previous season's 16 million bales.
In the week to Thursday, cotton prices were generally subdued on increased supply, especially in the northern region, traders said.
"Sluggish buying by mills and poor export enquiries pushed cotton prices downward in the midst of improved supplies this week," Amarsey said.
Traders said daily arrivals in India's Punjab region had risen to around 25,000/30,000 bales in the week just ended week, from 15,000 bales in the previous seven days.
Early this month, new crop arrivals dropped sharply in the northern region because of a severe cold spell, but they picked up after the weather improved, Amarsey said.
In the spot market, Bengal-deshi fell 40/50 rupees per maund (37.32 kg) to 770/825 rupees, while Punjab saw-ginned fell 10/45 rupees to 1,375/1,630.
Gujarat Sankar-4 (long-staple) fell 400/500 rupees to 16,500/17,000 rupees per candy (355.56 kg) for the average variety and to 18,000/18,500 rupees for the superior variety.

In Pakistan, prices are likely to ease as spinners have postponed buying until mid-February owing to general elections on February 3 and holidays for the Moslem festival of Eid al-Fitr on February 9-11, a dealer at Nasim Usman & Co said.
Another factor behind low purchases of cotton was a steep fall in export orders, the dealer said.
"Export orders are likely to rise sharply after the festival," he said.

Textile mills, which had already bought 5.979 million 375-lb bales up to January 15 compared with 5.860 million in the year-ago period, have retired to the sidelines, a broker at the private Karachi Cotton Association (KCA) said.
Some two million unsold bales have piled up at ginneries, which want the government to arrange the purchase of their stocks so that they can pay farmers, the broker said.
Government officials estimate the ex-gin production at nine million bales, enough for the local spinning industry's estimated needs of between 8.5 and 9.0 million bales.
Ginneries had received 7.867 million bales by January 15 compared with 8.287 million in the year-ago period, a Pakistan Cotton Ginners Association executive said.
The main reason for unsold stocks is a credit squeeze from December 1, a bank executive said.
In Pakistan's kerb market, the rate for the NIAB-78 variety ranged between 2,300 and 2,325 rupees per maund (37.32 kg), brokers said.
